title: revelation
comment: The making known of God's person, nature and deeds, in Scripture, history and supremely the person of Jesus Christ. God is also made known, to a limited yet important extent, through his creation.

children.title: revelation, through creation
children.comment: The creation bears witness to the wisdom and power of its creator. This natural knowledge of God is limited in its extent, but is sufficient to convince human beings of the existence of God and the need to respond to him.

children.title: The creation bears witness to its creator
All human beings have a natural awareness of God
The limitations of a natural knowledge of God
revelation, necessity of
children.comment: Finiteness and sin make it impossible to gain adequate knowledge of God through human effort alone. God in mercy makes himself known through the incarnation of the Son and the illumination of human minds to understand him.

children.title: The impossibility of fully knowing God without revelation
God is beyond unaided human knowing
The human mind is limited
The human mind cannot discern God of its own accord
God is known fully only through Jesus Christ
revelation, of God
revelation, in OT
children.comment: The OT bears witness to God's revelation in the history of Israel and in the inspired testimony of the prophets and other writers of the period. This knowledge of God prepares the way for the full disclosure of God in Jesus Christ in the NT.

children.title: Revelation in Eden and before the flood
The covenant framework of OT revelation after the flood
God's covenant with Noah

primaryrefs.comment: This covenant covers all living creatures.

children.title: God's covenant with Abraham
God's covenant with Moses at Sinai

seealsos.comment: Mount Sinai was also known as Mount Horeb

children.title: God's covenant with David
The promise of a new covenant
The recipients of OT revelation
The people of Israel
On occasions God spoke to people outside the covenant community

Direct communication
Visions and dreams
Visible manifestations (theophanies)
Scripture
The content of OT revelation
Revelation of God's will and purposes
Revelation of God's plan
Revelation of God's character and being
The incompleteness of OT revelation

primaryrefs.comment: The fulness of God's redemption could only become apparent with the fulness of his revelation in Jesus Christ.

children.title: revelation, in NT
children.comment: The NT fulfils and completes the revelation of God which began in the OT. Jesus Christ is the central focus of this self-revelation of God.

children.title: The unity and progress of revelation
The unity of OT and NT

seealsos.comment: The writings of Paul are presented as having equal status with the OT Scriptures
These sanctions have the same force as those of Dt 4:2; 12:32.

children.title: The progress of NT revelation
The NT fulfils and completes God's revelation of himself
Jesus Christ is the supreme revelation of God
Jesus Christ is the image of God
Jesus Christ has the nature of God
Jesus Christ is the exact representation of God
Jesus Christ is the incarnate Word of God
The role of the Holy Spirit in revelation
He is the divine agent of revelation
He is the source of revelatory manifestations
God's purposes in revelation
To reveal himself in Jesus Christ
To reveal his plan through Jesus Christ
revelation, responses to
children.comment: God requires and imparts a frame of mind that receives and responds to what he has made known.

children.title: God commands that his word be heeded
People do not naturally understand what God has revealed
They fail to recognise God's revelation in Jesus Christ
They fail to understand God's revelation in general
God has given his Spirit to illuminate the human mind
He reveals and teaches truth
He reveals through prayer for understanding
Understanding God's revelation carries special responsibility
God's revelation of himself will only be fully understood at the second coming of Jesus Christ

Repentance
